content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice CoC,
Nice CoC, would be great in Reverse & shortest mode as well! :)

Goal
* Consider changing "leaps" to "jumps" for consistency (up to you whether to change the title of the clash too).

Constraints
* Please revise the constraints as follows to match the actual cases (notice that < is changed to ≤ in two places, and the upper bound of [[J]] is reduced):

0 < [[D]] ≤ 10000
0 < [[J]] ≤ 100

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. write answer.

Cases
* Validator 3: Please revise the case such that [[D]] < [[J]], similar to Test 3.

* Please add a new pair of cases where [[D]] = [[J]].

* Please add a new pair of cases where
  • [[D]] > [[J]] > 10,
  • [[J]] is not a multiple of 5 or 10,
  • [[N]] > 5, and
  • the final jump covers the remaining distance exactly,
  e.g. [[D]] = 9180, [[J]] = 36.

Thanks.

Hello! 

Thanks a lot for all your inputs.
I think I adressed all of them. 

Please let me know if you see anything else!

Thanks again!
Thanks! Reverse might be tricky but I will definitely activate shortest code.

Actually, the 'tricky' part is what makes it fun here! :D 
Since it's a geometric progression (doubling distance), coders will recognize the 2^N pattern quickly. It's a very satisfying logic to crack in Reverse mode compared to string puzzles... Shortest and Fastest are great, but Reverse would be the cherry on top! :D

But it's up to you of course! :)

Looks mostly good to me, except that the upper bound of J should be increased from 100 to 255 because J is greater than 100 in some of the revised/new cases.

Thanks.
Corrected as well. Thanks for noticing!
